Bar one person, a young judoka from Jerusalem who qualified in London’s 2012 Games, they have all competed on a wild card scheme.The Palestinian Olympic Committee chooses its teams from Gaza, the West Bank and Palestinian communities across the world. So Fatima will face stiff competition while she makes do with scant resources.Gaza lacks an Olympic-size swimming pool and the few pools it does have struggle to stay open amid chronic energy shortages. It is also increasingly dangerous to swim in the sea.&nbspGaza’s environment authority said last year that nearly two-thirds of its 25 mile coastline was seriously polluted.&nbspSewage treatment plants cannot function due to the power&nbspshortages. The United Nations said that more than 100 million litres of waste water are pumped into the sea off Gaza every day.With filthy beaches and not enough electricity&nbspto keep pools clean, trying to train a swimming team is near impossible, according to the Olympic Committee in Gaza.&nbspIn a battered office and sat in front of a battery-powered fan, Munther Masalmeh, the committee’s secretary-general, said it would be a “major achievement” for a swimmer in Gaza to reach the Olympics.“There is not a single pool in Gaza that hits international standards. With our infrastructure problems it makes it even harder. It would be a major achievement to have a female swimmer here because of the lack of resources,” he told The Independent.The Israeli blockade also restricts access to sports equipment. Mr Masalmeh claimed even iron goal posts were banned because the Israelis feared&nbspthey could be used to make weapons.“Sports equipment gets stuck in the ports for year and does not reach the athletes. In addition, the Israelis have in the past banned players from leaving Gaza to participate in international tournaments,” he added.Nonetheless, Fatima hopes one day to get permission to leave Gaza and take her place at the Games.“I want to achieve my dream to be picked for the Olympics, so I can travel and compete in the 100m race,” she said, putting on her swimming pyjamas.“I don’t just want to participate, I want to get first place,&nbspso those who picked me are proud.”Enter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? story: The shadow sports minister claimed football supporters were reluctant to fly the England flag (Image: )The shadow sports minister claimed football supporters were reluctant to fly the England flag because of its connotations with the far-Right and Britain leaving the EU.Ms Allin-Khan told Westminster&rsquos The House magazine: &ldquoI think that many people feel that flying a St George&rsquos Cross is synonymous with far-Right ideology and that sometimes prevents them from doing so because they don&rsquot want to be perceived as such.&ldquoDuring previous World Cups between 2000 and 2010 you could walk 20 metres and see flags in windows, flags on cars, flags on shops.&ldquoDespite more sprouting up as the tournament went on, there&rsquos been a noticeable difference.She said the England flag has links to far-right ideology and Brexit (Image: )She added: &ldquoI think there is a reluctance to do so because shops may not want to feel they&rsquore not being welcoming to members of the community, and perhaps Brexit has a part to play in that.Her remarks not only sparked anger on social media, but also a study that found pride in the England flag had risen following the Three Lion&rsquos semi-final success during this year&rsquos tournament in Russia.Alexander Hall tweeted: &ldquoYou should have come round North Birmingham.&ldquoLoads of St George flags flying from windows and cars.He added: &ldquoTypical London Labour bubble MP turning her nose up at patriotism.Ms Allin-Khan had said the flag was associated with the National Front (Image: )Fiona Mellersh added: &ldquoHilarious. England flags.Her remarks sparked anger on social media (Image: )&ldquoOver the years, flying the flag has become more and more synonymous with the far-right - but why should they have any more right to fly the St George&rsquos Cross than you or I?&ldquoThe English flag has become associated with the national front, the EDL and other far right groups- it frustrates me.She added: &ldquoIt frustrates me because we have allowed this to happen.Fellow Labour MP Emily Thornberry was forced to resign in 2014 after appearing to mock a terraced house draped with England flags.Taking to Twitter, the then shadow attorney general - who lives in a plush &pound3million London home - shared a picture of the house which had a white van outside it.She captioned the snap &lsquoImage from Rochester&rsquo.

she had &ldquostitched up former Brexit secretary David Davis, and could have already completed the negotiation if she had spent &ldquoa quarter of the energy doing the same to the Eurpean Union.Mr Montgomery had appeared as a pundit on the BBC&rsquos Newsnight to defend his Brexit legacy.Host Emily Maitlis told him: &ldquoAs director of Vote Leave, you dedicated a year of your life to saying this would all be fine, that it was all going to be worked out.Christopher Montgomery claimed Theresa May had stitched up former Brexit secretary David Davis (Image: BBC&bull)&ldquoDavid Davis was saying it was going to be pretty easy, Liam Fox was talking about the ease of trade deals.&ldquoIt&rsquos a train wreck.Mr Montgomery shot back: &ldquoI think if Theresa May had put a quarter of the energy into stitching up the Europeans the way she stitched up David Davis, we&rsquod have Brexit done by this stage.&ldquoWe&rsquod have Calais back.David Davis resigned from the Government earlier this month in protest at the Chequers Brexit agreement thrashed out by Mrs May and her cabinet.The deal, which forms the basis of the Government's negotiating position with the EU, locks the UK into a &ldquosingle standards model and a &ldquocommon rulebook for goods, effectively forcing British manufacturers to abide by EU regulations after the UK leaves the bloc.In his resignation letter, Mr Davis criticised the plan, saying it would leave the UK in a &ldquoweak negotiating position at best.The Brexit secretary said the &ldquocurrent trend of policy and tactics was making it look &ldquoless and less likely that Brexit would deliver on the referendum result and the Tory commitments to leave the EU customs and single markets.Mr Davis said &ldquothe general direction of policy will leave us in at best a weak negotiating position, and possibly an inescapable one.

title: pakistan general election minority Ahmadi Muslim Imran Khan Nawaz Sharif Bilawal Bhutto Za
story: The majority of the district are Ahmadi Muslims (Image: )Up to 90 percent of Muslim voters in the north-east Punjab province have abstained from the forthcoming ballot because of outrage over voter cards that categorises them outside of their religion.The majority of the district are Ahmadi Muslims, which has not been given a separate category on the form, meaning voters of the strict faith have no other option but to classify themselves as non-Muslim for the sake of the election.The cards have sparked fury among Ahmadi Muslims who say they are being discriminated against and their minority sect has been negatively targeted.Salim Ud Din, a community spokesman, said: &ldquoIt's a matter of our faith so there can be no compromise on that.Community leaders have slammed an anti-Ahmadi rhetoric in the lead-up to the nation&rsquos general election as politicians seek to rally support among religiously conservative voters in the hope to head off challenges posed by Islamist parties.Ahmadi Muslims demonstrate the recognition of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad, who founded the sect in British-ruled India in 1889.They see him as a prophet but this is viewed by the Sunni majority as a breach of the Islamic tenet that the Prophet Mohammad was God's last direct messenger.By law they cannot call their places of worship mosques or distribute religious literature, recite the Koran or use traditional Islamic greetings, measures they argue criminalise their daily lives.Mr Sharif, also known as the Lion of Punjab, has never completed a stint in office  (Image: )Last year, a spat over proposed changes to the election law that would have eased some of the restrictions on Ahmadi Muslims participating in elections saw a group of them denounced on the floor of Pakistan's parliament.Election observers have said that should Pakistan&rsquos half a million Ahmadi Muslims were to participate, their vote could swing the results of more than 20 seats in Punjab, the most populous province where Pakistani elections are won and lost.Pakistan&rsquos election comes at a time of political instability.The election, which represents only the second democratic transition in a country that was ruled by the military for half its life, comes after a brief campaign.The 65-year-old took Pakistan’s national cricket team to to World Cup victory in 1992 (Image: )Cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan&rsquos centre-right Movement for Justice, also known as Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) is expected to be the main challenger to the ruling Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) party.The 65-year-old took Pakistan&rsquos national cricket team to to World Cup victory in 1992 and then entered politics five years later.Nawaz Sharif, who is 68 and the head of a wealthy industrialist family from Lahore, held the prime minister&rsquos office three times in the 1990s.But Mr Sharif, also known as the Lion of Punjab, has never completed a stint in office an has recently been ousted over corruption allegations.The 29-year-old son of assassinated former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari, is also due to stand.The poll will be held on July 25.

title: theresa may brexit claire foges
story: In 1893 plucky little Texan Jack Burke climbed into the ring to become champion of the American South.The match lasted 110 rounds and seven hours before the ref ended it — Burke had broken all the bones in his hands and was half dead but still carried on fighting.Theresa May is the political equivalent of that fighter: Determined, stubborn — but completely insane to carry on.The Prime Minister is permanently on the ropes. Blow after blow rains down on her authority. She is battered and bruised by her own party yet refuses to realise her time is up.The past few days have brought yet more resignations. Following the Foreign Secretary and the Brexit Secretary are ministers whose names escape me let’s call them Cuthbert, Dibble and Grubb.Though hardly well known, these MPs have grandly flounced off in protest at May’s handling of Brexit.In a particularly odd development, one is leaving the Government because he thinks the Government is not sticking to the spirit of government policy.All this on top of last week’s embarrassment, courtesy of Donald Trump. The President might have softened his comments about the Prime Minister and the “turmoil” afflicting the UK but the damage to May’s authority was done.God knows how this looks to the rest of the world. We used to bestride the international stage like a colossus now we stumble across it like Frank Spencer.The Prime Minister can’t take all the blame. She has been dealt a difficult hand — her party and the country split on Brexit, Europe turning the thumbscrews and Ukip waiting in the wings to hoover up Tory votes. It would be hard for any politician to make an outright success of this.But where Theresa May HAS failed categorically is on communicating her plans to the British people.The Chequers deal should have been a big moment. She should have been all over the TV stations selling this deal hard.In the past, prime ministers held public broadcasts to explain important matters to the people. Anthony Eden gave one on the Suez crisis, Harold Wilson on the devaluation of the Pound. Ted Heath warned in 1973 that the nation faced “the hardest Christmas that we have known since the war”.These leaders looked the nation in the eye, spoke directly to the British people — and LED.Theresa May, on the other hand, seems reluctant to get out and make the case for her own policy.Little wonder that two thirds of the public questioned on the Chequers deal were baffled by it. Confusion reigns.This points to a major problem with May’s premiership. She is hopeless at telling a national story.It’s the job of a leader not just to make decisions but to inspire the nation. For the person in No10, their words speak as loudly as their actions. They need to tell a compelling story about where Britain is going.Margaret Thatcher told the story of Britain emerging from the ashes of socialism thanks to the hard work and enterprise of its people: “A get-up-and-go instead of a sit-back-and-wait-for- it Britain.”Tony Blair told the story of Britain shrugging off the past and embracing the modern world: “A new Britain . . . a model 21st-century nation, based not on privilege, class or background, but on the equal worth of all.”David Cameron told the story of Britain clearing up the economic mess left by Labour, paying down our debts and living within our means.Love or loathe these leaders, at least they told a clear story about where Britain was going. We get none of this from May.She makes a virtue of just “getting on with the job”. But in a nation divided on Brexit, we desperately need more. We need a clear sense of direction for Britain’s future.Of course, the Prime Minister cannot last for much longer. In boxing terms she’s in the 12th round. Before long there will be a leadership contest — and those hoping to succeed May must learn from where she went wrong.The next resident of No10 must not only have the right policies but the right vision.If Britain is to regain its reputation abroad, and its self-respect at home, we urgently need a Prime Minister who inspires, who tells a national story — and who truly leads.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands of brits set to get up to 10k extra after bungling officials screw up benefits payments
story: Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced her department will have to pay out millions more to make up for previous errors.The extra cash will go to disabled claimants who were switched from Incapacity Benefit to Employment and Support Allowance between 2011 and 2014.An estimated 70,000 people are eligible for compensation of up to £10,000, with the average payout likely to be around £5,000.The DWP already faced a bill of £340million for claimants who lost out because of the departments mistakes from October 2014 onwards.Now the scheme is being extended as far back as 2011 following a scathing report from the Public Accounts Committee.The report found ESA claimants had been routinely underpaid after switching to the benefit.Hours after it was published, Ms McVey pledged to take further action to ensure that no disabled Brits miss out on what they should have received.She said: I hope this will help members to provide reassurance to their constituents who think they may have been affected that they will receive all the money they are entitled to.But campaigning MP Frank Field warned that ESA claimants had still been denied other benefits such as free school meals, dentists bills and NHS prescriptions.He said: The department failed to listen to claimants, charities and even its own staff when they sounded the alarm.Their warnings fell on deaf ears, and tens of thousands of people lost out as a result. The Government must now learn the lessons from this catastrophic failure as it faces the challenges of migration onto Universal Credit.The DWP will pay out the money over the coming months.

title: theresa may should go home
story: They did so by a huge margin. Sadly, a year or so later they also voted to keep the appalling Anna Soubry as their local MP. Let’s hope they never make that mistake again.For the last year this bilious, jabbering woman has done everything she possibly can to thwart the will of her electors.She is a staunch Remainer and is seemingly prepared to bring down the Government to get her way. Her actions suggest she couldn’t give a monkey’s about what the people in her constituency think.Two nights ago she was one of 12 Conservative rebels who voted against the Government. She wanted Britain to remain part of a customs union with the EU. That would mean — effectively — no real Brexit. And if they had won, it would have been catastrophe for the Government. And in my opinion, the country.The reason they didn’t lose is solely down to a bunch of courageous Labour MPs, including the excellent Frank Field, who voted with the Government. Soubry isn’t alone, of course. The people of Loughborough, Leics, also voted by a large margin to leave the EU.But they are represented in the House of Commons by Nicky Morgan, who appears not to give a toss what they think. She also voted for a customs union. Nicky is famous among many for being the second worst Education Secretary this country has ever had. She’s pipped to the post for that particular prize by Justine Greening.Being useless in their Cabinet posts isn’t the only thing that unites these two women. Greening is also opposed to Brexit and she has even called for a second referendum. Because she didn’t like the result of the first one.The people of Beaconsfield, Bucks, voted to leave the EU. But their MP, the grim Dominic Grieve, who resembles a funeral director from about 1923, appears not to care less. He has said he’s prepared to “collapse” the Government if he does not get his way.Sarah Wollaston is another one. Another embittered MP. Her constituency, Totnes in Devon, voted to leave by a sizeable margin.Because while it is true that the majority of Labour MPs are also opposed to Brexit, they have been nothing like as dangerous as the Tory rebels.We are in a mess. The Prime Minister staggers from crisis to crisis, striking meaningless deals whenever she can to stave off defeat for a few more days.She surely cannot last much longer. A Remainer herself, of course, I think she should be persuaded to call it a day. Go home, put her feet up. And let her party elect a leader who will take no more c**p from Brussels.And no more c**p from the likes of Soubry and Greening, either.THE top scientist Richard Dawkins – Britain’s most famous atheist – has got himself into trouble.He has said that he prefers to hear the sound of cathedral bells to the muezzin wail calling Muslims to prayer.  Saying something as inoffensive as that is enough to get you into hot water these days.Dawkins has been called a bigot as a consequence. I have to say I disagree with him. I love the sound of cathedral bells, sure.But I also enjoying hearing the Muslim call to prayer – when I’ve been on my travels in Morocco or Malaysia. But, over here, it’s cathedral bells for me every time.Here’s a tip, then.Take them to an expensive shoe shop and make them look at the display through the window.And remember the noise they make.KATIE PRICE is on holiday in Thailand and of course she’s got her baps out.  This might be a problem for Katie, pictured with boyfriend Kris Boyson.Topless sunbathing is against the law over there. This is because tourists enjoy looking at the scenic islands. Without having their view obliterated by a pair of breasts the size of Koh Samui.So watch yourself, Katie. And as a break from lying on the beach, how do you fancy a spot of caving?YOU’VE got to love the toffs, haven’t you?  Most of them are absolutely crazy after years of inbreeding.Take the brilliant Lizzie Purbrick who described herself as “a very well-bred toff”.  She went round to her married lover’s home after he’d cheated on her with a third woman.No messing with Lizzie. She took with her eight litres of pig’s blood which she sprayed across his flat. She daubed the words “slut” and “whore” and “big d**k lord” on his walls and sprayed a giant penis on the floor.  She said: “So many people have said I should write my life story, but I’m so bonkers I can’t remember it.”The judge said – in one of the great under-statements of the decade – that she had “real concerns about the defendant’s ability to make rational decisions”.No s**t, Sherlock.It started out a few years back with just a couple of stalls. Now the entire town centre is closed off and thousands turn up to pig themselves on cuisine from scores of nationalities.I got so stuffed last year I needed to be helped home. And not a chicken parmo – the supposed Teesside dish of choice – in sight.IT’S not often that the Labour peer Dame Margaret Hodge says something worth repeating. But in telling her party leader Jeremy Corbyn that he was a “f***ing anti-Semite and a racist” I think she kinda hit the nail on the head.Meanwhile, the decent, moderate Labour MP John Woodcock has resigned the party whip and become an independent.Long-time party members – like I was, until last year – know that Labour is currently led by a hard-left anti-Jewish rabble of thickoes.I hope the voters twig this sooner or later.AND now it’s time for Hypocrites of the Week. A special award for Pimlico Plumbers of London.They’ve put up a giant banner outside their premises about Brexit, saying: “Nobody voted to be poorer!”Pimlico Plumbers has just lost a landmark case brought by one of its employees. He, like almost all of their staff, was kept on a contract which allowed the firm to pay him less than the proper rate.They were done under a UK Supreme Court decision, using laws designed to stop unscrupulous firms exploiting cheap labour.I wonder what it is about the EU that Pimlico Plumbers likes so much? Can you take a guess?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: sun says irish pm leo varadkar
story: It has exposed beyond doubt both his crass naivety and the cynical deceit of the EU masters he cravenly obeys.Imagine the cataclysmic self-harm of Ireland preventing planes from its biggest trading partner flying over it. And the impossibility of its own airlines avoiding UK airspace. It won’t happen.Varadkar must believe that these grenades he brainlessly lobs into the Brexit negotiations help Brussels. He is not bright enough to realise how absurd and unstatesmanlike he looks.But he let something else very revealing slip too.Varadkar reportedly said that EU leaders have assured him no hard border or customs checks will ever be needed between Ireland and Northern Ireland.That’s under ANY scenario, including a No Deal.Since we will never build a hard border either, why is “avoiding” one still being discussed, let alone a huge sticking point?Answer: It is a ruse, confected by a Brussels desperate to keep us in its grip.Eurocrats yesterday tore apart Theresa May’s Chequers offer. Yes, the same offer already so over-generous it almost collapsed her Government.The Sun has never been more gloomy about the chance of a deal. There is nothing more Mrs May can compromise on.But Brussels is run by deluded bullies who apparently think they cannot lose.Martin Selmayr, the German who is effectively in charge, dislikes Britain and insists any deal must be punitive.The EU, while apparently negotiating with us, is also advising its members how to lure away our job-creating firms.Parliament, and its Remainers, must not be cowed. They must back Britain over Brussels. No Deal wasn’t our choice. But the EU is pushing us into it and telling its members to be prepared.Within eight months we must be fully ready too, economically and politically.THE huge surge in serious crime shames the supposed party of law and order.It is no coincidence murders, rapes, robberies and knife attacks are soaring with police numbers at a 36-year low.For years the Tories considered their necessary cuts to budgets safe enough. The evidence against is now irrefutable.But more cash is not the only answer.Many forces are appallingly led, obsessed with their image, with social media virtue-signalling and investigations driven by political correctness, all while ignoring the basics of keeping the public and their property safe.Home Secretary Sajid Javid must secure more money and reverse this horrific trend.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: diana would have known how to fix the meghan and thomas markle debacle
story: So many people have ­commented on the likeness between the late Princess Diana and Charlotte, the granddaughter she sadly never met.Diana often spoke of her desire for a daughter and she would have doted on Princess Charlotte.I can imagine proud Granny taking her to Disneyland and buying Princess outfits. She would have let Charlotte run riot in her bedroom, trying on all her designer clothes and shoes and raiding her make-up bag.It’s so tragic that all of these happy times were not to be. When William saw all of his children come into the world, most especially baby Charlotte, he must have felt the loss of his mother even more keenly.Diana would have been there with her arms full of presents, and not just for the babies. There would have been thoughtful gifts for Kate and lots of hugs and happy tears.You can well picture her ­giving newlywed Harry a cheeky nudge and telling him to “get on with it” so she could have more grandchildren to spoil.I also think that if Diana had still been alive this sad situation between Meghan Markle and her dad would never have been allowed to turn so toxic.Diana would have seen this potential problem looming even before the engagement was announced and nipped it firmly in the bud.She would have insisted and ensured he was invited to the UK and would have dispensed shrewd and invaluable advice on how to deal with all of the hoopla surrounding the wedding. Diana learned the hard way how to deal with the media and palace officials. She was misquoted, manipulated and misunderstood during her time as a royal wife and knew all the pitfalls and how to avoid them.Skittish Meghan would have been soothed and calmed and all of the bad feeling among the Markle family would have surely evaporated.Diana would have advised Meghan’s dad on his wedding suit, helped him with his speech and rehearsed him walking down the aisle.She would have put this rather shy and ordinary man completely at ease.Rather than watching his daughter getting married on TV while cowering in a cheap bed and breakfast in the US, he would have been an integral part of the happiest day of her life.Instead, we have a constant stream of ill-advised interviews given by Thomas where he appears to have been ignored and abandoned and, whether it’s fair or not, Meghan seems increasingly cold-hearted.Photos yesterday of. him celebrating his 74th birthday alone with just a fast food takeaway for company don’t exactly help, whether they were staged again or not.A present, phone call or card from Meghan would have gone a long way to build bridges.It’s all turning a tawdry soap opera meaning commentators such as Sharon Osbourne will keep the pot boiling.Just this week she inferred Thomas has a drink problem and should get clean, ensuring more lurid headlines and bad feeling as he furiously has to deny all of the allegations.No one is coming out of this well and never has Princess Diana been more missed.Harry needs her wise counsel and William knows what an important part she could have played in the lives of his ­children.I know her sons will never really get over her death, but I do hope when William looks into his daughter’s beautiful eyes he is heartened to see a reflection of his mum rather than finding it ­unbearably sad.THE way BBC News treated Cliff Richard was utterly shameful and I’m not in the least surprised it lost its court case.The poor man went through years of hell and became a virtual recluse – and his physical and mental health was profoundly affected.At a time when he should have been enjoying the rewards of a lifetime’s graft, he was enduring sleepless nights and often crying in anguish on the kitchen floor.Many in the media have expressed fear and disquiet that any sort of Cliff’s Law will mean restrictions on newspapers, radio and TV, and this is indeed troubling.But the blame should be pointed firmly at those who thought it was a good idea to send a helicopter to film and report an OTT police raid on an innocent man.Seeing Cliff outside the courtroom this week looking extremely fragile and on the verge of tears was heartbreaking.Clearly the sunny, friendly, optimistic Peter Pan of Pop has gone for good and in his place is a haggard, careworn, wary victim.Before the court case, Cliff told me he doesn’t have photos taken with fans and their children any more.It was painful to see the hurt and mistrust in his eyes.He then revealed this week that his VIP status meant he was allowed to use the secret Wimbledon tunnel under Centre Court and Court No1 to bounce quickly between both venues and view as much tennis as possible.Cliff doesn’t do that any more, and never will, because the tunnel goes past the ball boys’ changing area and he doesn’t want to put himself in a situation where he could potentially be accused of something unspeakable.I really hope that when enough time has passed he can get some of that old “glass half full” spirit back, but he will never be the person he was.And no one else should have to go through such a hideous ordeal when they have done nothing wrong.IF you don’t want to watch a movie that will make you laugh, cry and come out singing Abba songs, we can’t be friends.I thoroughly enjoyed Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – a rare example of a sequel that is better than the original.The starry cast includes Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, PIerce Brosnan, Andy Garcia and Colin Firth. But the cherry on the icing on the cheesecake is the legend that is Cher.I was lucky enough to host the world premiere this week in London and had the chance to talk to the cast, who were effusive in their praise of Her Cherness.It was surprising to hear she STILL gets nervous before going on set and she was genuinely bewildered by all the love in the air for her.I thought one elderly gay gentleman was going to explode with happiness when Cher blew him a kiss.It was so endearing – and there is nothing more deliciously camp than Cher stepping out of a helicopter in a blonde wig and sequins before going on to sing Super Trouper. She’s a class act and a throughly lovely woman.WATCHING politicians squabble like ferrets in a sack soon loses its novelty value – and our eyes are now glazing over whenever the dreaded subject of Brexit rears its ugly head.But we should never forget that when we woke up the day after the referendum – to discover a majority had voted to leave the EU – there was NO actual plan.Bupkis. Nada. Zilch. Diddly-squat.There wasn’t even a “to do” list.Instead, all the rats deserted the sinking ship, claiming the dog had eaten their homework or a big boy did it and ran away – leaving the (female) PM to tidy up their reeking mess. Funny that.No matter which way you voted, surely we can all agree on one thing.There was little or no thought put into how to actually implement such a seismic change. Not even a few notes on the back of a fag packet.Now, two years down the line, the whole big, fat mess is farcical and beyond parody.As a nation, we are a laughing stock.Shame on all those careerists and fence-sitters for their arrogance, stupidity and downright mendacity in not having even a half-arsed plan in place.A parcel of rogues, right enough.IF you fancy a right good laugh at some silly, bonkers, hilarious fun and games, tune in to BBC1 today at 5.05pm for another helping of Wedding Day Winners with myself and Rob Beckett.One couple will actually get married at the end of the show and it’s all very lighthearted and joyful.DID Burberry REALLY need to make a bonfire of its overpriced designer swag and burn an eye-watering £28million worth of clothing and cosmetics?In line with other designer labels, the fashion house claims the move was to stop counterfeiters getting their hands on garments and using them to produce fakes.But surely that just doesn’t add up.If criminals want to reproduce any designer clothes or handbags, they can go into any shop and purchase something – or, even simpler, just order it online.Could Burberry not instead have the mother of all sales in aid of Help for Heroes, or for the homeless charity Centrepoint, or any number of deserving causes here and in the Third World?That £28million would have gone a hell of a long way to help those in need.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: head teachers fun day ban for children absent just once in a year
story: Children as young as four have also been blacklisted after their parents kept them at home for only a single day through illness.It means just 29 of the 420 pupils at Maypole Primary School in Dartford, Kent, will be invited to the sports, arts and crafts event on Monday.Parents blasted the barmy ruling yesterday and claimed it punished children for things outside their control.Single dad Tommy Lynch, 38, said he kept his children, aged six and nine, at home on the anniversary of their mum’s death.The builder said: “I was fined for taking them away on the day and I’m happy to be punished for that because I’m an adult — but why punish the kids?”He added: “Even if the kids are minutes late it’s marked as an absence.”Lucy Cox said her son missed one day when she kept him at home with conjunctivitis for which he needed regular drops.She said: “If I’d sent him in, as advised, all the children and teachers would have had it within days. I am a teacher and value education, but this reward system helps no one.“One hundred per cent attendance is down to good luck or irresponsible parenting, neither of which seems right to reward. It shocks me it’s still allowed.“Children as young as four are being discriminated against.”Head Linda Wilmann said: “We’ve always had an annual award for those pupils who achieve 100 per cent attendance for the whole year. It’s a massive achievement and should be recognised.“Attendance and punctuality are crucial to ensure children get the most from their time at school.”Earlier this month two schools left devastated students sobbing when they refused to give them ice creams because of their bad attendance.GOT a story? title: jeremy corbyns strategists in private bust up over confusing brexit policy
story: Shadow International Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner complained in a meeting of Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinet that the party’s Brexit policy was too complicated to explain in the media.He told the private meeting it was “really hard” to explain Labour’s ‘six tests’ on Brexit - which were set out by Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer as a way to decide whether to back the Government’s final EU deal.Mr Gardiner was famously overheard calling the six tests “b*****ks” earlier this year.His outburst at the meeting last week sparked a furious reaction from Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer.He shot back: “It’s also hard doing any media when your colleagues are caught calling it b*****ks.”The pair have clashed on a number of occasions since joining the shadow cabinet - despite both being key figures in drawing up Labour’s Brexit policy.Last summer Mr Gardiner said being in a customs union with the EU would be “deeply unattractive” - only for Sir Keir to make it party policy six months later.And Sir Keir publicly rebuked Mr Gardiner after he described the Good Friday Agreement as outdated earlier this year.Shadow Cabinet sources refused to comment on the latest clash. title: philip hammond brexit betrayal eu borders
story: The Chancellor was at the centre of a row during the Prime Minister’s Chequers summit two weeks ago after appearing to suggest Britain’s borders should be on the Brussels negotiation table.He angered colleagues including Home Secretary Sajid Javid by insisting Britain needed to be given “maximum flexibility to negotiate.”Minutes from the Chequers summit stated that Mr Hammond argued in favour of offering preferential treatment to EU workers in a bid to win the backing of German Chancellor Angela Merkel.He urged Cabinet colleagues to keep options open for preferential mobility arrangements for EU citizens.But Mr Javid and Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said any perception that free movement was continuing would be toxic to voters.Mr Javid insisted “free movement had to end”, adding that there must be “no back door” for EU nationals after Brexit.The pro-EU Chancellor has been one of the biggest advocates for softer Brexit around the Cabinet table - to the fury of Leave supporting Tory MPs.But his allies insisted that he does not want to keep free movement for EU citizens to come to the UK forever - but was raising concerns about labour mobility after Brexit.Details of the tense standoff during the Brexit showdown at the PM’s country house are revealed today by Sun columnist James Forsyth.But sources close to Theresa May have insisted that that there is “no room in the PM’s mind for one iota of deviation on free movement.”They say: “If you can’t say free movement has ended, you can’t have a deal that’s sellable in any way.According to minutes seen by the Daily , he said: Such an agreement would be very important for the Chancellor of Germany.If the UK sought her help to deliver this deal, it would need to be prepared to negotiate on this point.But Mr Javid hit back by saying free movement had to end, insisting there must be no back door for EU nationals after Brexit.The minutes stated that the Chancellor disagreed with the Home Secretary on labour mobility and ending free movement.Revelations that Mr Hammond wants to put free movement on the negotiating table is likely to open up another explosive row with Tory Brexiteers.Our revelation comes as Mrs May faced fresh pressure to rule out giving any further concessions to Brussels as negotiations come to a head in the Autumn.Brexiteer Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom publicly warned that the Chequers plan must be the final offer rather than an opening gambit.But Mrs May risked fresh wrath from her MPs by refusing to explicitly rule out further concessions to Brussels.Asked if Mrs Leadsom was correct to describe the Chequers agreement as Britains final offer to the EU, a spokesman for the PM would only say: The proposals that we put forward in the White Paper are what we believe to be the only credible and realistic way to move the negotiations forward and that was made clear numerous times by the PM.”Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt sparked further fears by twice refusing to describe Chequers as the “final offer”.He would only say: “It’s our substantive offer I think is the best way to phrase it,” during a visit to Scotland. Our journalists title: jacob rees mogg says brussels chiefs are acting like the mafia this is why
story: The Brexit ringleader hit out out at the EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier’s grumpy press conference saying it showed “why we are right to be leaving the mafia-like European Union.Italian Mafia crime families are famed for their organised protection racketeering - with the comparison likely to incense Eurocrats.The arch-Leaver later explained to The Sun that the “the EU seems to behave like the Mafia so that if you want to leave it then retaliates by behaving unreasonably even at cost to itself.”He added: “Who would want to belong to such an organisation?”Mr Rees-Mogg also took aim on Twitter at gobby Irish premier Leo Varadkar’s “aggressive” claims he would block Irish airspace to British planes if Brexit talks collapsed.However last night prominent Tory Remainer Anna Soubry let rip at Mr Rees-Mogg claiming he was a “force of darkness.”Reigniting bitter public sniping between the Tory factions, the ex-Minister said Jacob Rees Mogg and his Brexiteer colleagues in her own party were “now running Theresa.”She raged: “Since the referendum, the forces of darkness have taken over and they have continued to take over and this week if there was every any doubt who was running this government it was quashed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: steve mogford united utilities yacht salary
story: United Utilities CEO Steve Mogford has trousered £12m in just five years - despite his company wasting 439 MILLION litres of water a day from leaky pipes.The Daily Mail reports Mr Mogford, 63, owns the 80ft Sea Samphire, air-conditioned throughout and docked in a picturesque marina in Menorca.He is also said to own a luxury villa on the island.The lavish boat comes with a bar, a barbecue, a dining room, and even a jet ski.The custom boat is decked out in teak furniture and has flat-screen TVs in every room.Its brochure boasts: It offers custom-made, spacious entertaining and ensures all your needs are catered for – from dining alfresco while the crew takes the helm, to sipping champagne on the huge flybridge or sleeping soundly between the finest bedlinen in the quietest of cabins.Bury North Labour MP James Frith raged: His customers would be dismayed to learn he has such a high pay packet through which he can afford to own a yacht.Manchester Central Labour MP Lucy Powell added that it was a particularly galling example of excess in utility companies.She added: Constituents would be appalled to learn that, at a utility company which really should be a public asset, executives are paid so much they can afford to lead this kind of lifestyle.

title: britain to swelter in 35c temperatures next week as bookies slash odds on uks hottest day ever
story: As one heatwave ended last week, another is about to sweep in to keep Brits toasty - just as the summer holidays kick off.With Met Office experts confidently predicting 35C heat bookies have slashed the odds on Brits enjoying the hottest ever day to just 2/1.The record currently stands at 38.5C - taken in 2003 at Brogdale, near Faversham, Kent.Public Health England issued a warning for Brits to make sure they protect themselves from harmful UV rays as temperatures creep ever higher.Met Office forecaster Steven Keates said: “After 31C on Sunday, Monday sees a step up in temperatures to 32C, with Tuesday and Wednesday seeing a chance of 33C – and I wouldnt bet against 34C locally.“The second half of the week is likely to stay hot, with a more pronounced southerly feed meaning potential for a degree or two more, with 35C shown on forecast models.“The following week looks like things further hot weather in the South and East.”But even before we get there things are looking bright and sunny, with the fine weather returning after a series of thunderstorms and downpours yesterday.The Met Office said today could get to near-30C, and would be followed by 31C tomorrow, 32C on Monday and 33C or 34C on Tuesday and Wednesday.Thunderstorm warnings were in place across most of south-east England until the end of yesterday, with much of the UK seeing some rain.Forecasters probably wont need to extend them into Saturday although heavy rain was persisting in the South West and Wales.There were concerns earlier over potential travel disruption as holidaymakers began to set off following the start of the school break.Clouds this morning should later make way for afternoon sunshine, with temperatures expected to reach 29C (84F) in London.Mr Keates said: There will still be dribs and drabs of drizzly rain in places but the amount of rain at this stage should probably not be much.Most places will see some sunshine by the afternoon but there still will be quite a lot of cloud in some places - it wont be wall-to-wall sunshine.Sunday will be the better of the two days, with England seeing fine, dry weather, sunny spells, with the mercury rising above 30C (86F).The South East and parts of Wales will experience temperatures in the mid-20s, rising on Sunday, while north-west Scotland will see cloudier and wetter conditions.As of Wednesday, the UK had just 1.85in (47mm) of rain, making it the driest start to summer in modern records which date back to 1961, followed by 2013 with 2.3in (59mm) of rain.

title: hero pilot plane landing storm hail nose russia
story: Hero captain Nikolay Satostin, 28, managed to guide the the Polar Airlines turboprop to safety after a freak storm ripped the fuselage apart.He brought the plane down in Siberias Yakutsk Airport after a 665-mile flight from Olenyok.Horrifying pictures show how the full extent of the damage to the An-24s nose.Most of the planes white paint has been blasted clean off, with a series of gaping holes at the very tip of the nose.Moscow-based air safety watchdog Rosaviation has set up a commission to investigate the incident.Investigators have already ruled out lightening being the cause.Nose damage can be caused by birds - but the plane flew through a giant thunderstorm as it approached Yakutsk - the worlds coldest city.The airline has so far not given details.

title: amazing make up artist who has shocked 50m on youtube with her terrifying transformations
story: Serbian Mirjana Kika Milosevics startling vanishing act is just one of dozens of startling makeovers which have sent the internet into meltdown.The Serbian skin illusionist runs a YouTube channel with 50million views where she creates remarkable, mind-bending visions with nothing more than a bit of body paint.Mirjana colours her body in interesting and bizarre ways to create optical illusions.She has been painting her own body to create incredible costumes and mind-boggling illusions for over two years.Mirjana revealed: I couldn’t find a job in my city so I decided to paint murals and kids faces. First I need one day to relax, listen to some music and then get inspired.Then I prepare my make, up my three mirrors and I start to paint. title: tube commuter singing deep purple smoke on the water
story: Hilarious footage shows the moment the tube goer fearlessly unleashes a whopping pair of lungs on the politan Line.As Londoners sat on the Uxbridge-bound train, the performer let go of his inhibitions to perform his rendition of the rock hit.One passenger can be seen tapping their foot while another holds her head in her hands.At one point the singer appears to sneeze, temporarily disrupting the show. But it doesnt deter him for long and he continues to wail as the tube pulls into Finchley Road station.He even continues as the song enters the instrumental stage.The video was posted to a Facebook group dedicated to broadcasting the daily antics of Londoners.Some social media users claimed they recognised the soulful singer, saying they had seen him at various station around the capital.More than 1,000 people reacted to the post, which has been shared hundreds of times.User Elle Boogie commented: This is the best thing I’ve seen on here in the longest while!Brilliant! title: karren brady prime minister legacy
story: Because . . . ’twas ever thus — right? Politics is a man’s world and, to many, women still feel like token visitors.Even when Tony Blair famously had 101 “babes” in his 1997 intake of MPs, only four of his Cabinet appointments were female.Here we are, 20 years later, and yes, we have a female Prime Minister but there is still a prevailing view that the Cabinet, in particular, belongs to men.Clearly there’s something profoundly wrong with that equation.Given that this country is made up, more or less equally, of men and women, things would undoubtedly be fairer, not to mention calmer, if more women were on board.So the big question is, why aren’t there?Things are better than they were. Since the 2017 election there are 208 women in the Commons, up from 191 in 2015.But there are still not enough and you don’t have to look far for reasons why that might be.Most women are put off by the environment and the culture and wonder why on earth they would want to put themselves within a country mile of either.Take Prime Minister’s Question Time, which appears to be a bunch of overgrown public school boys booing, jeering and jostling with each other in their bid to establish who is top dog.What woman in her right mind would choose to enter that fray?Then there are the practicalities. This week, Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson was “cheated” in a crunch Brexit vote by the breaking of her pairing pact.This is an arrangement where one MP agrees not to vote to cancel out the fact that another MP on the opposite side is unable to vote — in this case Swinson was at home with her three-week-old baby.The problem was, her pairing partner reneged on the deal and voted.Then there are the hours, which can be difficult if you have a family. Any woman would need a very understanding partner and family to do the job.Also, any MP is opening themselves up to the line of fire and a lot of personal criticism — which multiplies for female MPs.Some have to deal with endless comments and speculation about their appearance, as well as threats of rape and death on a regular basis. Just this week a man was arrested over abusive Facebook posts aimed at various female MPs.If it’s true voters are biased against women, any female has to be ten times as talented, determined and tenacious to get the job in the first place.It’s no wonder women are put off entering politics.But if we want true equality then more women need to go into Westminster and the culture needs to change.That is why I support the campaign group Women To Win and will be taking part in an event called The Voice Of Women In Politics.The idea is to try to encourage more women into Parliament, outlining some of the changes that need to take place to raise the number of female candidates.Getting more women into politics is a no brainer.Women tend to work collaboratively to solve problems whereas — in my experience — men are more likely to lock horns, point fingers and try to shout the loudest. All too often men are interested in progressing to be a leader, whereas women are more focused on getting the job done.And when women DO find their voice in politics, it can be very powerful, and they often hae the balls to say things that men just wouldn’t.Look at Tory minister Anna Soubry, who this week suggested the PM should take control of her hardliner MPs and stop pandering to the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg.I know she’s got a lot on her plate at the moment, but if I was Theresa May I would be spending a good proportion of my time and energy on making real changes to politics in order, specifically, to attract many more women.It could be one of the greatest legacies she could hope for.Thomas Markle is a concerned dad who just wants to be reconnected with his daughter.Meanwhile this HALF-sister has turned a constant shade of green and wants to get involved in any way she can.Is it any wonder she wasn’t invited to the wedding?MY heroine of the week is 21-year-old Emilia Holden a waitress in Georgia, US, who was at the end of a shift when a customer casually grabbed her bottom as he walked past.Her response? She followed him, grabbed him and body slammed him to the ground, then called the police – after which he spent two nights in a police cell.What a fantastic response. Good for her.But also, who are these men that think that they can just grab a woman’s behind just because they want to?But hearing about elaborate plans by Pixie Lott which include a total of 18 bridesmaids all wearing the same dress, left me feeling a bit stressed out.Apart from anything else, it will take them all an hour to travel up the aisle.JAMES GODDARD-WATTS, the businessman whose family founded the hardware firm Screwfix, is still locked in a multi-million pound divorce battle with his ex-wife, Julia.They reached an agreement eight years ago ­– following the end of a 13-year marriage – that Mrs Goddard-Watts should get a £3.25million house and a £4million lump sum.But she complained that Mr Goddard-Watts had not revealed the full extent of his wealth at the time of the settlement and court fights began.Critics say Julia is a leech, greedy and after his money.But when you consider the worth and value of building a home, looking after children and a family while supporting a spouse, that should be worth at least half of whatever the partner who didn’t do all of that has earned in the meantime.So why shouldn’t she take him back to court?The law states that assets are divided equally.So people who hide theirs from their spouse only have themselves to blame if said spouse feels forced to take them to court to get what’s fair.ELLE Macpherson’s diet regime is enough to make me reach for the pizza delivery menu.The model is up at 5am. She has warm water, lemon and cayenne pepper.She has no booze, almost no carbs, no meat and no dairy. She is such a follower of the alkaline diet – based on the theory you can change the pH of your body through food – that she checks the acidity of her urine.I’m sure the diet is good for her – but who wants to add years to your life if those years are going to be so, well, dull?“The only chance I have of being on TV again is if I were very ugly,” he said.“I think only old, ugly women can get on TV. Like Mary Beard.”David added that he would only be hired now: “If I had tombstone teeth and rather funny hair and made a lot of noise about that fact.”Oh dear.Where even to start? When you resort to attacking someone’s appearance, you are in trouble.It’s not Mary Beard that has held back his career. It’s David himself.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ayesha hazarika clusterfudge pm dishcloth leadership
story: The Tories are so busy plotting against each other they have forgotten there is a country to run.They have become a circular firing squad. Or a crap remake of Fight Club — except they DO talk about Fight Club. All the time.Theresa May has the leadership skills of a damp dishcloth, no authority and no political vision.A strong leader needs a clear mission. You may not agree with it, but you know what they stand for.“Live each day like it’s your last,” is our Prime Minister’s political strategy, except she’s not dancing in the rain.She is waiting for the sharks to circle. And soon they will come for her.Buffoon-in-chief Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg — a man so old-fashioned he could have been dug up by Time Team — wait to pounce. And Brexit is a mess. Things are so bad, even Elon Musk is out of ideas. No one will be happy with where we end up.And because there is no party political or Brexit majority in the Commons, politics is stuck, trapped in what feels like a never-ending Brexistential crisis.Normally, I’m with “Brenda From Bristol” when it comes to more elections and referendums.But maybe a People’s Vote on the final deal or another election is the only way to unblock Brexit.Think of it like a political plunger — unpleasant, nasty but necessary.You’d think the Opposition would be gleefully capitalising on all this chaos. Think again. Instead of going after the Tories, Labour has decided to traumatise the Jewish community. Again.Labour has had a horrible problem with anti-Semitism, yet instead of healing the wound, it has poured vinegar on it by choosing not to adopt the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance code of conduct.These guys sound pretty authoritative and the code is good enough for government departments and the Crown Prosecution Service.Many Jewish groups and leaders, including the Chief Rabbi, are distraught, confused and angry. And you can see why.This shameful decision led to an angry clash outside the Commons chamber where Jewish MP Margaret Hodge confronted Jeremy Corbyn, allegedly calling him an anti-Semite and a racist.Hodge lost family in the Holocaust and fought off the BNP in her Barking and Dagenham constituency.Instead of acknowledging her pain and offering to sit down with her, Team Corbyn are taking disciplinary action against her.I bet they deal with her far quicker than they did with Ken Livingstone, who couldn’t stop banging on about Hitler.What dark times for Labour, which once had a proud tradition of fighting racism. They must sort it out.Then we have the Lib Dems, who have proved useless. They have one policy — stop Brexit.Yet leader Vince Cable and ex-leader Tim Farron missed crucial votes on Monday. Talk about Dem and Dumber.To top it all off, the DUP’s Ian Paisley Jnr has been suspended for 30 days — which hasn’t happened since 1949 — for failing to declare lavish holidays to that well-known Northern Irish stakeholder, Sri Lanka.And to think Theresa May planned to give MPs an extra five days off as a reward for all their hard work.The country has had enough of these fools’ infighting, incompetence and filling their boots. Especially when we face so many big problems, from NHS funding to housing.Parliament’s end-of-term report is a big, fat fail. British politics should be taken into special measures.THE premiere of Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again was sun-kissed, frothy fun –  and no one mentioned the ­Customs Union. Bliss.The stars were out in full, including Cher. She is magnificent, but it is a little odd that at 72 she has fewer wrinkles than any other cast member, including 29-year-old Lily James. And the baby.She told Lorraine Kelly it was down to not drinking, smoking or doing drugs. Yeah, right.We women may be naive when it comes to the quest for eternal beauty, but we ain’t stupid.WHEN you hear of people getting up in the middle of the night and queuing, you think of the Boxing Day sales or the release of the latest Apple gadget.You don’t think of childcare.Yet more than 100 parents queued from 3am – armed with chairs, flasks and biscuits – trying to bag their child a coveted place in the breakfast club at a primary school in Cardiff.For many working parents, breakfast clubs are a lifeline.They can drop off the children in a safe environment where they can get a decent breakfast, then make it to work on time themselves.Though parents have the right to request flexible working hours, many fear the sack if they come in late.These spaces were limited and dished out on a first-come, first-served basis, which is why the parents took such drastic measures.This shows how desperate parents are for childcare that matches their working hours.The scrapping of Labour’s extended school programme and the first real-terms cuts to schools mean all these extras that were provided are no longer affordable.Childcare isn’t a luxury.It’s a necessity for millions of families and they are crying out for more breakfast and after-school clubs.JEFF BEZOS, the boss of Amazon, is a man clearly in his “Prime”.He’s now the richest man in modern history.Good for him.I’m all for celebrating entrepreneurs and hard work – but shouldn’t that apply to his poor workers toiling away in his warehouses?They would probably give Amazon working conditions zero stars.I wish our business leaders remembered some of their forefathers, who felt a moral and civic responsibility to look after their employees and took some pride in that.It makes business sense too. Happy workers are better workers.So after Bezos pops open the champagne, maybe he could spare a thought for his staff, who told an undercover reporter they pee in bottles because the loos are too far away and they are afraid of being accused of time-wasting.C’mon, Jeff – that’s really taking the p**s. ONE school in Liverpool had to apologise after kids as young as four were left in tears when they were denied an ice cream treat because they didn’t have a 97 per cent attendance record.How mean is that? What if they were ill? And surely it’s the parents’ fault.CARERS got another kick in the teeth this week when the Court of Appeal overturned a decision that those doing sleep-in shifts should earn at least the minimum wage.If the decision had gone through, it would have cost the UK care sector billions – so charities and local governments were relieved.But it shows what a raw deal carers get.Judges said only hours spent awake counted as work – but that is completely out of touch with the reality of what carers do.Many of the elderly and vulnerable people they look after need their help through the night, whether it’s a trip to the loo, to take medication or dealing with more serious situations such as seizures. Carers can’t exactly fall into a deep sleep. They have to be alert and listening in case they are needed.The rooms they sleep in may not be comfortable and they will be away from their own families.Many carers are paid so little that they live hand to mouth and barely get by.When I met a group in the West Midlands, they told me they couldn’t afford to put the heating on in winter and had to take their kids to the grandparents’ for tea once or twice a week just so they would be fed.Some were struggling so much they had to visit food banks.But they also loved their jobs and took great pride in looking after their clients as if they were family.They get paid a pittance, with some earning just £30 for a ten-hour shift.These low-paid workers – the majority of whom are women – are unsung heroes and deserve more.New Health Secretary Matt Hancock must make social care a priority and enforce minimum-wage law properly.It’s time we took better care of our carers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: disruptive passenger emergency landing munich
story: The Thomas Cook Airlines flight from Belfast International Airport to Dalaman was rerouted to Munich when a man became abusive and aggressive towards the crew.The unscheduled landing at Munich Airport took place on Thursday evening, according to Belfast Live.German police were waiting on the runway for the flight to land so that they could attend to the disruptive passenger.It is understood that another man and woman were also taken off the flight.One passenger said: He was abusive and aggressive and the pilot took the decision to detour to Munich where we waited on the runway while he was removed and laid out on the tarmac.Reportedly, a passenger had to support an air hostess in trying to calm the abusive customer.The aggressive behaviour continued and the passenger was so said to have upset those around him by using foul language.The staff decided to move a young family to elsewhere on the plane because the commotion had made the kids cry.Following this series of events, the pilot reportedly told the passengers to buckle up their seat belts in preparation for landing.When the plane landed, holidaymakers saw police waiting on the runway to arrest the aggressive man.Despite delays of almost two hours, the passengers seemed to be understanding of the situation.One said: No one on the plane seemed very upset. The pilot was quick to explain that its not a decision he made lightly but it was for the safety of passengers and staff.Everyone was very supportive of the staff in helping them gather rubbish to reduce the cleaning time for the flight back to Belfast.A Thomas Cook Airlines spokesman said: The safety and security of our customers and crew is always our first priority.On July 19, flight MT850 from Belfast to Dalaman was diverted to Munich due to a disruptive passenger.The flight continued to Dalaman and arrived at 01:58 local time. We are very sorry for the delay and inconvenience caused to our customers.

title: worlds last remaining tribes remote islands jungles
story: The man - thought be in his 50s - is believed to hunt with a bow and arrow for survival and has been filmed felling a tree.He is believed to be the only survivor of a group of six killed during an attack by farmers and land grabbers in 1995.But, despite his isolation and the lack of contact with the outside world, the man is not alone in his remote lifestyle within sprawling untouched lands.In fact, according to Survival International, there are more than one hundred uncontacted tribes around the world.But who are they and how do they survive? And what does the future hold for the tribes in the face of deforestation and the growing use of technology?The Sentinelese are an uncontacted tribe living on North Sentinal Island, one of the Andaman Islands in the Indian Ocean.They reject all contact with outsiders, according to Survival International, and are thought to have inhabited the island for nearly 60,000 years.They are known to throw arrows at low flying aircraft and after the 2004 Tsunami a photo showed one aiming an arrow at an emergency helicopter.The Kawahiva - a small group of uncontacted Indians living in Brazil’s Amazon rainforest - have survived numerous genocidal attacks.Survival International say very little is known about them, because they have no peaceful contact with outsiders.They live a nomadic lifestle - a result of violence and the destruction of their forest home.The Jarawas are an indigenous people of the Andaman Islands in India.They face many threats including a road built through their territory which brings thousands tourists into their land.They have largely shunned interaction with outsiders.The Dani tribe live in the highlands of Western New Guinea, Indonesia.They were unwittingly discovered by American philanthropist, Richard Archbold, after an expedition in 1938.They are well known for their unique practice of self-mutilation which involves cutting off the top part of their fingers when a loved one dies.The Lacandón people live in the Lacandon jungle in the state of Chiapas, Mexico.In 2015 there were less than 300 members remaining and they are direct descendants of the ancient Maya civilization.They cut all possible contact from the outside world and called themselves Hack Winik, meaning True People.The Mashco Piro - who live in the jungle in Peru - had historically rejected outsiders.But in 2015 they started to appear in populated areas.They are said to have been displaced by illegal loggers, gold miners and oil companies, as well as drug traffickers.

title: buffy the vampire slayer to get a reboot and a brand new lead actress
story: Agent Of S.H.I.E.L.D. writer Monica Owusu-Breen will write the contemporary adaptation as well as acting as an executive producer.Original series creator Joss Whedon will also oversee production of the show.The Hollywood Reporter, which first revealed the reboot, said the new series will be "diverse, with some aspects of the series&#8230 seen as metaphors for issues facing society today". The original TV series ran for seven seasons, from 1997 to 2003, inspiring 1999 spin-off show Angel.However, the show itself was actually a reboot of sorts, based on a 1992 comedy horror film of the same name and also written by Whedon.The film, which had moderate success at the box office, starred Luke Perry, Donald Sutherland, Hilary Swank and Kristy Swanson in the lead role of Buffy.While some fans of the original feminist parable welcomed the reboot news, others were more sceptical.Voice artist Justin Frac wrote: "This is the best news in all of history!!!!!!!", following up his tweet with: "And props to the three black slayers we got on Buffy the Vampire Slayer's original run: Nicki Wood, Kendra Young and Rona."However, author Lilliam Rivera had mixed feeling, tweeting: "I loved Buffy. But you know what else I love? When Hollywood looks at new stories by people of color instead of rebooting old ones and changing the casting."     I don’t think it’s a coincidence that the anniversary of #btvs is the same week as #internationalwomensday. I have always believed that the world is changed by your example, not by your opinion. We have all learned a lot from Buffy, and the best part is, that never ends. “From now on, we won’t just face our fears, we will seek them out. We will find them, and cut their hearts out one by one. There is only one thing on earth more powerful than evil, and that’s us” Scroll through for some behind the scenes pictures, then and now (hopefully there will even be some you have never seen) #buffyslayday A post shared by  Sarah Michelle (@sarahmgellar) on Mar 10, 2018 at 9:47am PST Whedon previously expressed his "fear" at the idea of a reboot or reunion when speaking to The Hollywood Reporter for the show's 20th anniversary.Describing reboots as a "monkey's paw", he admitted: "You have to meet expectations and adjust it for the climate, which is not easy."Luckily most of my actors still look wonderful, but I'm not worried about them being creaky. I'm more worried about me being creaky as a storyteller. You don't want that feeling that you should have left before the encore."A network is not yet attached to the new Buffy series.

title: novichok investigators in hazmats continue search at public toilets
story: The toilets are cordoned off with protective screens, and swabs have also been taken from a park bench.Sky News' Lisa Dowd, who is at the scene, said: "This is believed to be one of the areas where Charlie Rowley and Dawn Sturgess visited before they fell ill."The forensic intensification at this scene will probably continue throughout the day." Mr Rowley and Ms Sturgess were exposed to the deadly nerve agent after handling a contaminated bottle later found at Mr Rowley's home in Amesbury, near Salisbury.In March, the Wiltshire cathedral city was the scene of the novichok poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, who both survived.Admitted to hospital on 30 June, Ms Sturgess, 44, later died, while Mr Rowley, 45, was discharged on Friday, three weeks after falling ill.Mr Rowley's brother, Matthew, told Sky News he was "ecstatic" at his brother's release from hospital, but expressed surprise at his swift recovery given only a few days previously he had still seemed very weak.Mr Rowley said: "He's obviously improved in his condition.Mr Rowley said his brother's recollection of what happened was "very vague", but added: "He definitely said to me that they found this bottle of something and Dawn sprayed it on her wrists and that he picked it up and broke it somehow - and that's how he got it on his hands."Public Health England medical director Paul Cosford has said Mr Rowley's discharge from hospital does not pose a risk to the public.He added: "Our advice to the public remains unchanged. Do not pick up any items such as syringes, needles, cosmetics or similar objects made of materials such as metal, plastic or glass."If you didn't drop it, then don't pick it up." Detectives are investigating the possibility - described by Mr Rowley's brother - that Ms Sturgess tested the spray on her face and hands, believing it to be perfume.The mother-of-three's death is being treated as murder.

story: NewsLilia Djairine death: Mum-of-one died from hanging not stab woundsPolice are now treating the death of Lilia Djairine, 24, as "unexplained" after she was found injured in the street outside the pizzeria she ran in Ealing&nbspShareByLiz Dunphy14:00, 21 JUL 2018Updated15:01, 21 JUL 2018NewsLilia Djairine, 24, was found seriously injured on the street at lunchtime and was pronounced dead at the scene&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-one found dead outside her family's restaurant died from hanging, a post mortem has revealed.
